Text: France is just too strong. Another Lyneel spike takes the set, 25-23, and the match, 3-0. That's two wins here in Kyoto this weekend for France. Great volleyball from the visiting Europeans!
With France ahead 23-21, Asano delivers an ace. 23-22. But then Rouzier fires a spike, to give his side a match point.
Julien Lyneel brings another spike to edge France ahead 21-19.
Sibide connects on another hard spike from out wide. It seems every time France uses him, he connects. 17-16 for the visitors.
A Kuriyama spike brings Japan within one at 15-14, and then they draw even when a Julien Lyneel spike sails wide. 15-15.
After a hard Sibide spike puts France up 13-8, Japan puts together a run of three scores to make it 13-11, capped by a nice Akihiro Yamauchi tip.

As expected, France edges back ahead 7-5 on a wonderful block by the towering Kevin Le Roux. Japan's Yuta Matsuoka does not help his team's cause, firing an attack off the line judge. 8-5 at the TTO for France.
An Ishikawa spike gives Japan another rare lead against France, 3-2.

The explosive Earvin Ngapeth is somewhat of a fan favorite here in Japan. French coach Laurent Tillie has him resting now, with Lafitte, Marechal, and Sibide as the front three to start the third set.
Ishikawa fights off a set point with a wonderful block on France's Mory Sidibe, but a Hiroaki Asano serve sails long to hand the second set to the visitors, 25-18. 2 sets to 0, for France.
Shimizu finally comes in for Japan, but hands France set point with a spike to the net. 24-16.
A miscommunication by Japan on defense, and a ball drops for a France score. They can't make mistakes like this today.

Rouzier continues to give Japan headaches, another hard spike finding its target, pushing France ahead 19-13. He has five points in this set alone. Beyond Yanagida, Japan isn't mustering much of an attack to counter.

A great rally, with Japan scrambling on defense, ends in a Masahiro Yanagida score, pulling the home side within four at 13-9. Yanagida played well late yesterday, with six points in the third set. Of note, coach Nambu has yet to use his hard-hitting captain Kunihiro Shimizu today.
After exchanging points early, France jumps ahead thanks to more great attacking from Rouzier. A cross-court kill from Ngapeth helps extend France ahead 8-4.
Japan takes the opening point of the second set on a France net violation. It's their first lead. Let's see if they can build on it.

France's Antonin Rouzier clinches the first set for the visitors with a block stuff on Masahiro Yanagida. France takes the set with ease, 25-15. They're maintaining the composure they showed in yesterday's win.

Ishikawa, who had just one point in limited action on Saturday against France, is showing some spark here late in the first with a couple of explosive spikes. Japan is still way behind at 22-15, and Japan's coach Nambu opts to put in Hiroaki Asano in place of the young star.

Yuki Ishikawa and Masahiro Yanagida connect on consecutive spikes for Japan, but France still comfortably ahead at 11-6. Japan will have to do better than this, or they'll have the same result as yesterday.
France jump out to a quick 8-2 lead, thanks to great serving early by Earvin Ngapeth, including an ace.
Warm-ups all finished. Just a few minutes to start time!
Team Japan were dominated in the first two sets yesterday against France, but managed to generate some momentum in the third. They hope to carry that over into today's match.
Another beautiful day in Kyoto, and the fans are out to cheer the home team against France today. Yesterday, the visitors pulled off a relatively easy 3-0 win here at Shimadzu Arena.
